  "document_summary": "This issue of the official gazette 'Kuwait Today' (Al-Kuwait Al-Youm) for March 23, 2025, comprehensively covers a wide array of governmental and legal affairs in Kuwait. It features numerous Decree Laws (No. 14-26, 28-38, 40-46, 48-53) linking the budgets of various ministries, public authorities, and institutions for the fiscal year 2025/2026, alongside detailed financial reports and estimates. The gazette also includes approvals for international agreements, such as headquarters agreements with the Olympic Council of Asia and the GCC Center for Emergency Management, and a Memorandum of Understanding on Consular Cooperation with Austria, in addition to ratifying the Middle East Green Initiative Charter. Furthermore, it publishes decrees on appointments, nationality revocations, amendments to traffic laws, and decisions concerning minors' nationality status. A significant portion is dedicated to bankruptcy and restructuring proceedings for several companies, regulations on anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing, and a multitude of tender announcements, awards, and extensions from various government entities. The issue concludes with official announcements regarding company liquidations, commercial agency registrations, public auctions for vehicles and real estate, and criminal judgments from Kuwaiti courts.",

# Council of Ministers / Majlis Al-Wuzara <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>
## Decree-Law No. 14 of 2025
### Regarding the Linkage of the Budget of Ministries and Government Departments
### for the Fiscal Year 2025/2026

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Decree-Law No. 106 of 1976 regarding the Future Generations Reserve, amended by Law No. 18 of 2020,
- And Decree-Law No. 31 of 1978 regarding the rules for preparing public budgets, controlling their implementation, and the final account, and its amending laws,
- And Decree No. 84 of 2024 regarding ministerial succession and deputization, and its amending decrees,
- And based on the submission of the Minister of Finance / Wazir Al-Maliya <orig>وزير المالية</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers / Majlis Al-Wuzara <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
- We have issued the following Decree-Law: -

### Article One
The revenues in the budget of ministries and government departments for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at KWD 18,231,486,000.

### Article Two
Expenditures in the budget of ministries and government departments for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at K.D. 24,538,000,000 (twenty-four billion, five hundred and thirty-eight million Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig> only), distributed among the chapters listed in Table (B) attached to this Decree-Law.

### Article Three
The deficit of revenues over expenditures is estimated at K.D. 6,306,514,000 (six billion, three hundred and six million, five hundred and fourteen thousand Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig> only).

### Article Four
The Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> and the Ministers <orig>الوزراء</orig> – each within their respective competencies – shall implement this Decree-Law, which shall be published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> and shall come into effect from April 1, 2025.

# Decree-Law No. 17 of 2025
## Regarding the Appropriation of the Budget of the Public Authority for Civil Information <orig>الهيئة العامة للمعلومات المدنية</orig>
## for Fiscal Year 2025/2026

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Law No. 32 of 1982 regarding the Civil Information System, and Decree-Law No. 31 of 1978 regarding the rules for preparing public budgets, controlling their implementation, and the final account, and its amending laws,
- And Law No. 3 of 2003 regarding the procedures for issuing certain annexed and independent budgets and their final accounts, amended by Law No. 8 of 2015,
- And Decree No. 84 of 2024 regarding ministerial succession and deputization, and its amending decrees,
- And based on the presentation of the Minister of Finance <orig>وزير المالية</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
- We have issued the following Decree-Law:

### Article One
The expenditures in the budget of the Public Authority for Civil Information <orig>الهيئة العامة للمعلومات المدنية</orig> for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at an amount of KD 44,478,000/- (Kuwaiti Dinar <orig>دينار كويتي</orig>).

## Article Two
The revenues in the budget of the Public Authority for Minors' Affairs <orig>الهيئة العامة لشئون القصر</orig> for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at K.D. 2,380,000 (Two million three hundred eighty thousand Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig> only), as stated in Table No. (2) attached to this Decree-Law.

## Article Three
The excess of expenditures over revenues is estimated at K.D. 23,224,000 (Twenty-three million two hundred twenty-four thousand Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig> only), as stated in Table (Cont. -2) attached to this Decree-Law, and shall be covered from the budget of Ministries and Government Departments – Ministry of Finance <orig>وزارة المالية</orig> (Public Accounts) for the fiscal year 2025/2026.

## Article Four
The Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> and the Ministers – each within their respective competencies – shall implement this Decree-Law, which shall be published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> and shall come into effect from April 1, 2025.

# Decree-Law No. 24 of 2025
## Regarding the Budget Linkage of Abdullah Al-Salem University <orig>جامعة عبد الله السالم</orig>
## for the Fiscal Year 2025/2026

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Law No. 76 of 2019 regarding Public Universities, amended by Decree-Law No. 156 of 2024,
- And Decree-Law No. 31 of 1978 regarding the rules for preparing public budgets, monitoring their implementation, and the final account, and its amending laws,
- And Law No. 3 of 2003 regarding the procedures for issuing certain annexed and independent budgets and their final accounts, amended by Law No. 8 of 2015,
- And Decree No. 84 of 2024 regarding Ministerial Substitutions and Delegations, and its amending decrees,
- And based on the presentation of the Minister of Finance <orig>وزير المالية</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
- We have issued the following Decree-Law:

### Article One
The expenditures in the budget of Abdullah Al-Salem University <orig>جامعة عبد الله السالم</orig> for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at an amount of KD 31,280,000/-.

The expenditures in the budget of the Public Authority for Roads and Land Transport <orig>الهيئة العامة للطرق والنقل البري</orig> for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at K.D. 5,317,000 (Five Million, Three Hundred and Seventeen Thousand Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig> only), in accordance with Schedule (B) attached to this Decree-Law.

### Article Three
The losses resulting from the estimated expenditures exceeding the estimated revenues in the budget of the Public Authority for Roads and Land Transport <orig>الهيئة العامة للطرق والنقل البري</orig> for the fiscal year 2025/2026, amounting to K.D. 5,312,000 (Five Million, Three Hundred and Twelve Thousand Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig> only), shall be carried forward in accordance with Schedule (C) attached to this Decree-Law, as carried-forward losses within the Authority's capital transferred from the State's General Budget for the fiscal year 2025/2026.

### Article Four
The Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> and the Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree-Law. It shall be published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> and shall come into effect from April 1, 2025.

## Regarding the Budget Allocation for the Kuwait Anti-Doping Agency <orig>الوكالة الكويتية لمكافحة المنشطات</orig>
### For the Fiscal Year 2025/2026

*   And based on the presentation by the Minister of Finance <orig>وزير المالية</orig>,
*   And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
*   We have issued the following Decree-Law:

### Article One
The revenues of the Kuwait Anti-Doping Agency <orig>الوكالة الكويتية لمكافحة المنشطات</orig> for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at KWD 334,000.

The revenues in the budget of the Public Authority for Industry <orig>الهيئة العامة للصناعة</orig> for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at an amount of 153,845,000 KD.

### Article Two

K.D. (one hundred forty-one million nine hundred seventy-eight thousand Kuwaiti Dinars only) in accordance with Schedule (A) attached to this Decree-Law.

### Article Two
The expenditures in the budget of the Central Bank of Kuwait <orig>بنك الكويت المركزي</orig> for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at K.D. 64,886,000 (sixty-four million eight hundred eighty-six thousand Kuwaiti Dinars only) in accordance with Schedule (B) attached to this Decree-Law.

### Article Three
The net profit resulting from the increase of revenues over expenditures, amounting to K.D. 77,092,000 (seventy-seven million ninety-two thousand Kuwaiti Dinars only), shall be added and disposed of in accordance with the text of Article (17) of Law No. 32 of 1968, and in accordance with Schedule (C) attached to this Decree-Law.

### Article Four
The Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> and the Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree-Law, which shall be published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> and shall come into effect from April 1, 2025.

<header>
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue 1731, Seventy-First Year 67
Sunday 23 Ramadan 1446 AH – 23/3/2025 AD
</header>

And upon Law by Decree No. 6 of 1980 regarding the establishment of Kuwait Petroleum Corporation <orig>مؤسسة البترول الكويتية</orig>, amended by Law No. 54 of 1982.
And upon the Decree issued on 11 Rabi' Al-Awwal 1401 AH corresponding to 17 January 1981 AD, concerning the financial principles related to the marketing of crude oil and gas belonging to the State
by Kuwait Petroleum Corporation <orig>مؤسسة البترول الكويتية</orig>.
And upon Decree No. 84 of 2024 regarding Ministerial Substitutions and Delegations, and its amending decrees.
And based on the submission of the Minister of Finance <orig>وزير المالية</orig>.
And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>.
We have issued the following Law by Decree:

### Article One
The revenues in the budget of Kuwait Petroleum Corporation <orig>مؤسسة البترول الكويتية</orig> for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at K.D. 23,069,125,000 (twenty-three billion, sixty-nine million, one hundred and twenty-five thousand Kuwaiti Dinars only), in accordance with Table No. (1) attached to this Law by Decree.

### Article Two
The expenditures in the budget of Kuwait Petroleum Corporation <orig>مؤسسة البترول الكويتية</orig> for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at K.D. 22,854,846,000 (twenty-two billion, eight hundred and fifty-four million, eight hundred and forty-six thousand Kuwaiti Dinars only), in accordance with Table No. (2) attached to this Law by Decree. The Corporation is permitted to exceed the variable cost of purchasing crude oil, gas, and (Kaif) products, provided that this is offset by an increase in sales revenues.

### Article Three
The net profits for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at K.D. 214,279,000 (two hundred and fourteen million, two hundred and seventy-nine thousand Kuwaiti Dinars only), in accordance with Table No. (3) attached to this Law by Decree.
And shall be distributed in accordance with the text of Article (12) of Law by Decree No. (6) of 1980.

### Article Four
The Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> and the Ministers – each within their respective competencies – shall implement this Law by Decree, which shall be published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> and shall come into effect as of April 1, 2025.

Amir of Kuwait <orig>أمير الكويت</orig>
Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>

Acting Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء بالنيابة</orig>
Fahad Yusuf Saud Al-Sabah <orig>فهد يوسف سعود الصباح</orig>

Minister of Finance <orig>وزير المالية</orig>
Noura Sulaiman Salem Al-Fassam <orig>نوره سليمان سالم الفصام</orig>

only, and that is in accordance with Schedule (B) attached to this Decree-Law.

### Article Three
The operating results of the Insurance Regulatory Unit <orig>وحدة تنظيم التأمين</orig> for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at KD 1,691,000 (one million six hundred ninety-one thousand Kuwaiti Dinars
only, and shall be disposed of in accordance with what was stipulated by Article (15) of Law No. (125) of 2019 regarding the regulation of insurance, and that is in accordance with Schedule
(C) attached to this Decree-Law.

### Article Four
The Prime Minister and the Ministers – each within their respective competencies – shall implement this Decree-Law, and it shall be published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>, and shall come into effect from the first of
April 2025.

### Article Two
The expenditures in the budget of the Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development <orig>الصندوق الكويتي للتنمية الاقتصادية العربية</orig> for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at K.D. 27,967,000 (Twenty-seven million, nine hundred sixty-seven thousand Kuwaiti Dinars only), in accordance with Schedule (B) attached to this Decree-Law.

### Article Three
The net profits of the Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development <orig>الصندوق الكويتي للتنمية الاقتصادية العربية</orig> for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at K.D. 253,449,000 (Two hundred fifty-three million, four hundred forty-nine thousand Kuwaiti Dinars only), in accordance with Schedule (C) attached to this Decree-Law. The profits shall be distributed in accordance with Article (3) bis of Law No. 25 of 1974 regarding the Reorganization of the Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development <orig>الصندوق الكويتي للتنمية الاقتصادية العربية</orig> and Article (30) of the Articles of Association of the Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development <orig>الصندوق الكويتي للتنمية الاقتصادية العربية</orig>.

### Article Four
The Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> and the Ministers <orig>الوزراء</orig> - each within their respective competencies - shall implement this Decree-Law, which shall be published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> and shall come into effect as of April 1, 2025.

K.D. (one hundred and eight thousand Kuwaiti Dinars only) in accordance with Schedule (A) attached to this Decree-Law <orig>مرسوم بقانون</orig>.

### Article Two
The expenditures in the budget of Zakat House / Bait Al-Zakat <orig>بيت الزكاة</orig> for the fiscal year 2026/2025 are estimated at K.D. 22,088,000 (twenty-two million and eighty-eight thousand Kuwaiti Dinars only) in accordance with Schedule (B) attached to this Decree-Law <orig>مرسوم بقانون</orig>.

### Article Three
The funding from the budget of ministries and government departments and the Ministry of Finance / Wizarat Al-Maliya <orig>وزارة المالية</orig> (Public Accounts) for the fiscal year 2026/2025 for the budget of Zakat House / Bait Al-Zakat <orig>بيت الزكاة</orig> is estimated at K.D. 21,980,000 (twenty-one million nine hundred and eighty thousand Kuwaiti Dinars only) in accordance with Schedule (C) attached to this Decree-Law <orig>مرسوم بقانون</orig>.

### Article Four
An amount of K.D. 30,000 (thirty thousand Kuwaiti Dinars only) is allocated to Zakat House / Bait Al-Zakat <orig>بيت الزكاة</orig> as an annual subsidy from the budget of ministries and government departments (Ministry of Finance / Wizarat Al-Maliya <orig>وزارة المالية</orig> – Public Accounts) for the fiscal year 2026/2025.

### Article Five
The Prime Minister / Ra'ees Majlis Al-Wuzara' <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> and the Ministers – each within their respective competencies – shall implement this Decree-Law <orig>مرسوم بقانون</orig>, which shall be published in the Official Gazette / Al-Jarida Al-Rasmiya <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> and shall come into effect as of April 1, 2025.

### Article Two
The expenditures in the budget of the Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research <orig>معهد الكويت للأبحاث العلمية</orig> for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at K.D. 46,149,000 (forty-six million, one hundred and forty-nine thousand Kuwaiti Dinars only), in accordance with Schedule (B) attached to this Decree-Law.

### Article Two
The expenditures in the budget of the Capital Markets Authority <orig>هيئة أسواق المال</orig> for the fiscal year 2025/2026 are estimated at KWD 37,967,000 (only thirty-seven million, nine hundred and sixty-seven thousand Kuwaiti Dinars), as stated in Table (B) attached to this Decree-Law.

### Article Three
The deficit resulting from the excess of expenditures over revenues, amounting to KWD 33,287,000 (only thirty-three million, two hundred and eighty-seven thousand Kuwaiti Dinars), shall be covered from the Authority's General Cash Reserve <orig>الاحتياطي النقدي العام للهيئة</orig>, as stated in Table (C) attached to this Decree-Law.

### Article Four
The Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> and the Ministers <orig>الوزراء</orig> – each within their respective competencies – shall implement this Decree-Law, and it shall be published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>, and shall come into effect as of April 1, 2025.

### Article Two:
The excess of revenues over expenditures amounted to K.D. 39,051,607/655 (thirty-nine million, fifty-one thousand, six hundred and seven Kuwaiti Dinars and 655 fils only), in accordance with Schedule (C) attached to this Decree-Law, and shall be distributed as follows:
a- An amount of K.D. 5,287,082/800 (five million, two hundred and eighty-seven thousand, eighty-two Kuwaiti Dinars and 800 fils only), representing 10% of the net operating profits, shall be transferred to the new projects reserve or for supporting existing projects.
b- An amount of K.D. 33,764,524/855 (thirty-three million, seven hundred and sixty-four thousand, five hundred and twenty-four Kuwaiti Dinars and 855 fils only) shall accrue to the State's Public Treasury <orig>الخزانة العامة للدولة</orig> in accordance with Article (38) of Law No. (56) of 1996.

### Article Four:
The Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> and the Ministers – each within their respective competencies – shall implement this Decree-Law, which shall be published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> and shall come into effect as of April 1, 2025.

# Decree-Law No. 55 of 2025
## Approving the Headquarters Agreement
## Between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>
## And the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig>

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qa'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to May 10, 2024,
- And Law No. 6 of 2006 regarding the Agreement signed between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig>,
- And Decree No. 84 of 2024 concerning Ministerial Substitutions and Delegations, and its amending decrees,
- And based on the submission of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,
- We have issued the following Decree-Law:

### Article One
Approval of the Headquarters Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig>, signed in Kuwait City <orig>مدينة الكويت</orig> on November 26, 2024, the texts of which are attached to this Decree-Law.

## Explanatory Memorandum
### Regarding Decree-Law No. 55 of 2025
### Approving the Headquarters Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait
### And the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig>

Stemming from the historical relations enjoyed by the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> through its membership in the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>اللجنة الأولمبية الآسيوية</orig> since 1982, and in a desire to achieve further support and patronage for the Asian Olympic Movement <orig>الحركة الأولمبية الآسيوية</orig>, and to enhance it through the support of the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>حكومة دولة الكويت</orig>, this Headquarters Agreement <orig>اتفاقية المقر</orig> between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>حكومة دولة الكويت</orig> and the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig> was signed on November 26, 2024, in Kuwait City <orig>مدينة الكويت</orig>.

Article (1) addressed the definitions of the terms contained therein and the interpretation of their meanings. Article (2) clarified the legal personality of the Council, stating that it possesses the necessary legal personality to contract, negotiate, acquire movable and immovable property, and has the capacity to litigate. Article (3) explained the purpose of this Agreement, which is to regulate the legal status of the Council regarding privileges and immunities. Article (4) referred to the facilities provided by the Host State, whereby the Government of Kuwait <orig>حكومة الكويت</orig> is committed to providing essential services for the Council to perform its duties and achieve its objectives, as well as providing public services such as postal, telephone, and communication services. Article (5) stipulated that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارة الخارجية</orig> of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> shall be the sole concerned entity for communication with the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig>.

Article (6) clarified the immunity of the Council, stating that no employee or person holding public authority may enter its premises to carry out a duty related to their position except with explicit written permission from the President. The Government shall take all necessary measures to protect the building and prevent material damage or disruption to its security, provided that the Council's premises are not used for purposes inconsistent with its powers and objectives. Furthermore, the Council's building may not be used to grant asylum to any person, especially those legally convicted of crimes they committed, those fleeing justice, those wanted for arrest, or those ordered by the Government to be deported outside the country.

Article (7) stipulated communication facilities, stating that no censorship shall be imposed on the official correspondence and communications of the Council. The Council also has the right to install wired and wireless communication devices, provided that the necessary approvals are obtained, with the Council being exempt from all related fees and expenses.

Article (8) defined the immunities and privileges of the Council members, stating that Council employees who are not citizens of the Host State shall enjoy several immunities and privileges, including: freedom of movement and transit within the territory of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, judicial immunity for all their official statements, writings, or actions, even after their official capacity ceases, and exemption from tax on salaries and remunerations they receive from the Council. Article (9) stipulated the immunities and privileges of representatives of National Olympic Committees <orig>اللجان الأولمبية الوطنية</orig> and Asian Olympic Federations <orig>الاتحادات الأولمبية الآسيوية</orig>, stating that representatives of the National Committees of member states, as well as international and Asian federations invited to Council meetings – who are not representatives of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> – shall enjoy the same privileges and immunities mentioned in Article (8) of this Agreement while performing their various duties at the Council and during their travel to and from the meeting venue.

Article (10) clarified that the application and interpretation of the provisions of this Agreement shall be based on relevant international agreements concerning the immunities and privileges granted to international organizations and their personnel. Article (11) stipulated how disputes arising from the interpretation or implementation of this Agreement shall be settled between the two parties through diplomatic channels via consultations and negotiations. Article (12) included procedures for entry into force, amendment, and termination, stating that it shall enter into force from the date of the last notification by which the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>حكومة دولة الكويت</orig> informs the Council of the completion of all necessary constitutional procedures for its entry into force. It may be amended by mutual agreement of the parties, and such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures stipulated in paragraph (1) of this Article. This Agreement may be applied provisionally after its signing in accordance with the provisions of Article (25) of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties of 1969. This Agreement shall remain in force for a period of five years and shall be automatically renewed for similar period(s) unless one of the parties notifies the other party in writing, through diplomatic channels, of its intention to terminate it six months prior to its expiry date.

Since this Agreement serves the interest of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and does not conflict with its obligations in the Arab and international spheres, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارة الخارجية</orig> requested the preparation of the necessary legal instrument for its ratification.

And whereas this Agreement, according to its provisions, requires ratification by law in accordance with the text of the second paragraph of Article (70) of the Constitution, its approval shall therefore be by law in accordance with the provision of this paragraph.

Therefore, the necessary draft Decree-Law for its approval, along with its explanatory memorandum, has been prepared and attached in the appropriate legal form.

Therefore, the accompanying Decree-Law approving it, along with its explanatory memorandum, has been prepared.

### Headquarters Agreement
Between
The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig>

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig>, hereinafter referred to as "the Parties",

And stemming from the historical relations enjoyed by the State of Kuwait through its membership in the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>اللجنة الأولمبية الآسيوية</orig> since 1982.

And desiring to achieve further support and sponsorship for the Asian Olympic Movement <orig>الحركة الأولمبية الآسيوية</orig>, and to strengthen it through the support of the Government of the State of Kuwait.

And whereas the Government of the State of Kuwait has agreed to host the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig>,

And in completion of the agreement issued pursuant to Law No. 6 of 2006 regarding the agreement signed between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig> in Kuwait City on 28/6/2003,

They have agreed as follows:

### Article 1
### Definitions

For the purposes of this Agreement, the terms listed below shall have the meanings assigned to each of them as follows:
*   **The Government**: The Government of the State of Kuwait
*   **The Host State**: The State of Kuwait
*   **The Council**: The Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig>
*   **The President**: The President of the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig> elected by the General Assembly of the Council.
*   **Council Staff**: The staff and experts of the Council whose names are communicated by the Council to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارة الخارجية</orig> of the State of Kuwait.

- Headquarters: All buildings and their parts, and the attached courtyard occupied by the Council.
- Council's Assets: The Council's funds, properties, and assets, wherever located in the State of Kuwait, shall enjoy immunity.

## Article 2
### Legal Personality
The Council shall enjoy the legal personality necessary for contracting, negotiating, acquiring movable and immovable assets, and the capacity to litigate.

## Article 3
### Purpose of this Agreement
Without prejudice to the applicable laws and regulations in the State of Kuwait, the purpose of this Agreement is to regulate the legal status of the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig> with regard to the privileges and immunities enjoyed by the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig> and its staff in the State of Kuwait, as an international organization.

## Article 4
### Facilities Provided by the Host State
The Government undertakes to provide the following:
1. A permanent headquarters for the Council, equipped with all necessary services for the performance of its duties and the achievement of its objectives.
2. General services necessary for the Council, such as postal, telephone, and communication services in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement, in addition to electricity, water, and fire prevention services.

### Article 5
### Relationship with the Host State

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the State of Kuwait <orig>وزارة خارجية دولة الكويت</orig> shall be the sole and exclusive authority responsible for communication with the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig> within the Host State.

### Article 6
### Immunity of the Council

1.  The premises of the Council's headquarters shall be inviolable. No official or person exercising any public authority may enter them to perform a duty related to their function except with explicit written permission from the President, and under the conditions approved by him. In case of necessity, serious reasons must be present for entering the Council.
2.  The Government shall take all necessary measures to protect the premises and prevent their intrusion, material damage, breach of security, or undermining of their dignity, provided that the Council's premises are not used for purposes inconsistent with its powers and objectives.
3.  The archives and documents of the Council shall be inviolable.
4.  The Council shall have the right to display its emblem on its premises.
5.  In accordance with the laws and legislations in force in the Host State, the Council may open bank accounts.
6.  The Council's funds and the means of transport and communication it uses shall not be subject to inspection, seizure, confiscation, or similar coercive measures.
7.  The Council, its movable and immovable property, and its other assets shall be exempt from all direct taxes. This exemption does not include fees collected for the use of public facilities or in exchange for public services. The Council shall also be exempt from customs duties, prohibitions, and restrictions imposed on the export and import of materials exported or imported by the Council for its official use. Furthermore, the Council shall be exempt from introducing securities and foreign currencies into the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> or transferring them to another country.
8.  Under no circumstances shall the Council's premises be used to grant asylum to any person, especially those legally convicted of crimes they have committed, those fleeing justice, those wanted for arrest, or those sentenced by the Government to deportation outside the country.

### Article 7
#### Facilities and Communications
1. The official correspondence and communications of the Council shall not be subject to censorship. The Council has the right to use codes in its correspondence and communications and to utilize all necessary means of communication, including diplomatic bags.
2. The Council has the right to install wired and wireless communication devices, provided that the necessary approvals are obtained for this purpose. The Council shall also be exempt from all related fees and expenses.

### Article 8
#### Immunities and Privileges of Council Members
Without prejudice to the provisions of the agreement on the advantages and privileges of Council employees who are not nationals or permanent residents of the host state, to enable them to perform their functions, the following privileges and immunities shall apply:

1. Freedom of movement and passage, while observing the regulations and instructions concerning prohibited or restricted areas for reasons related to national security.
2. Judicial immunity for all acts, words, or writings performed in their official capacity. This immunity shall continue even after they cease to hold their official status.
3. Immunity from arrest, detention, or confiscation of personal luggage, vehicles, documents, manuscripts, all personal belongings, and intrusion into private residences.
4. Exemption from tax on salaries and emoluments received from the Council.
5. They and their families shall be granted the right to obtain necessary residency permits and re-entry visas, as well as in relation to returning to their home country in times of crisis.

### Article 9
#### Immunities and Privileges of Representatives of National Olympic Committees and International and Asian Federations
Representatives of the National Olympic Committees of member states, as well as international and Asian federations invited to the Council's meetings – excluding representatives of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> – shall enjoy, during the exercise of their functions related to the Council and their travel to and from the meeting venue, the same privileges and immunities stipulated in Article (8) of this Agreement.

2. The Kuwaiti Ministry of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارة الخارجية الكويتية</orig> shall be considered the sole point of contact with the Olympic Council of Asia <orig>المجلس الأولمبي الآسيوي</orig> within Kuwait <orig>الكويت</orig>.

# Article 11
## Settlement of Disputes
Any dispute that may arise regarding the interpretation and/or implementation of this Agreement shall be settled between the Parties through diplomatic channels, and through consultations and negotiations.

# Article 12
## Entry into Force, Amendment, Termination
1. This Agreement shall enter into force from the date of the last notification by which the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> informs the Council of the completion of all necessary constitutional procedures for its entry into force.
2. This Agreement may be amended by mutual consent of the Parties, and such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures stipulated in paragraph (1) of this Article.
3. This Agreement may be applied provisionally after its signature, in accordance with the provisions of Article (25) of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties of 1969.
4. This Agreement shall remain in force for a period of (5) years, automatically renewable for a similar period or periods, unless one of the Parties notifies the other Party in writing and through diplomatic channels of its intention to terminate it, six months prior to its expiry date.

- And on the resolutions of the Ministerial Council of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> regarding the establishment of the GCC Emergency Management Center <orig>مركز مجلس التعاون لإدارة حالات الطوارئ</orig>, which were adopted at the 121st session of the Ministerial Council,
- And on Decree No. 84 of 2024 concerning Ministerial Substitutions and Delegations <orig>الحلول والإنابات الوزارية</orig>, and its amending decrees,
- And based on the proposal of the Minister of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزير الخارجية</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
- We have issued the following Decree-Law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig>:

### Article One
Approval of the Headquarters Agreement <orig>اتفاقية مقر</orig> between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Gulf Cooperation Council Emergency Management Center <orig>مركز مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية لإدارة حالات الطوارئ</orig>, signed in Kuwait City <orig>مدينة الكويت</orig> on November 25, 2013, the texts of which are attached to this Decree-Law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig>.

### Article Two
Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree-Law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig>, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

**Amir of Kuwait <orig>أمير الكويت</orig>**
**Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>**

**Acting Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء بالنيابة</orig>**

**Abdullah Ali Abdullah Al-Yahya <orig>عبد الله علي عبد الله اليحيا</orig>**

Issued at Seif Palace <orig>قصر السيف</orig> on: 18 Ramadan 1446 AH
Corresponding to: March 18, 2025 AD

## Explanatory Memorandum <orig>المذكرة الإيضاحية</orig>
### For Decree-Law No. 56 of 2025
### Approving the Headquarters Agreement <orig>اتفاقية مقر</orig> between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Gulf Cooperation Council Emergency Management Center <orig>مركز مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية لإدارة حالات الطوارئ</orig>

movable and immovable property, and the capacity to negotiate. Article (3) clarified the purpose of this Agreement, which is to define the tasks undertaken by the Center through privileges and immunities. Article (4) referred to the facilities provided by the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, whereby the Government is committed to allocating land for the establishment of the Center's permanent headquarters in accordance with the procedures and mechanisms in force in the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>. Article (5) clarified the Center's immunity, whereby the Government shall take all necessary measures to protect the building and prevent its intrusion, material damage, breach of security, or degradation of its dignity, provided that the Center's buildings are not used for purposes inconsistent with its powers and objectives. The Article also stipulated tax exemptions for the Center's funds and prohibited the use of the Center's building as a refuge for any person, especially those legally convicted of crimes they committed or those fleeing justice. Article (6) specified communication facilities, stating that official correspondence and communications of the Center shall not be subject to censorship. Article (7) specified the immunities and privileges of the Center's members, whereby the President, his deputy, and the Center's staff who are not citizens or residents of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> shall enjoy numerous immunities and privileges, including: freedom of movement and passage within the territory of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, and judicial immunities for all that emanates from them in their official capacity, whether spoken, written, or acted, even after the cessation of their official capacity. Article (8) stipulated the immunities and privileges of representatives of national committees, whereby representatives of the national committees of member states, other than representatives of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, shall, during the exercise of their duties related to the Center and their travel to and from the meeting headquarters, enjoy the same privileges and immunities stipulated in Article (7) of this Agreement. Article (9) clarified that the provisions of this Agreement shall be applied and interpreted based on relevant international agreements concerning immunities and privileges granted to international organizations and their staff. Article (10) stipulated the method for settling disputes arising from the interpretation and implementation of this Agreement, or any other disputes falling within its scope of work or in which the Center is a party, through amicable means of dispute resolution, negotiations, conciliation, and arbitration. Article (11) included procedures for entry into force, amendment, and cancellation, whereby it shall enter into force from the date of the last notification by which the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> informs the General Secretariat of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>الأمانة العامة لمجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> of the completion of all necessary constitutional procedures for its entry into force. It may be amended by mutual agreement of the parties, and these amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures stipulated in paragraph (1) of this Article. This Agreement may be terminated by either party by written notification to the other party. This Agreement shall remain in force for a period of five years and shall be renewed for similar period(s) unless one of the parties notifies the other party in writing and through diplomatic channels of its intention to terminate it six months prior to its expiry date.

Based on the resolutions of the Ministerial Council of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> regarding the establishment of the GCC Emergency Management Center <orig>مركز مجلس التعاون لإدارة حالات الطوارئ</orig>, which were adopted at the 121st session of the Ministerial Council, and in light of the State of Kuwait's <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> approval to host the aforementioned Center, a Headquarters Agreement <orig>اتفاقية مقر</orig> was signed on November 25, 2013, in Kuwait City <orig>مدينة الكويت</orig>, between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Gulf Cooperation Council Emergency Management Center <orig>مركز مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية لإدارة حالات الطوارئ</orig>, to establish the necessary rules for the Center's establishment in Kuwait City <orig>مدينة الكويت</orig> in accordance with the hosting conditions, immunities, and privileges determined by the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> to achieve the objective of establishing the Center.
Article (1) addressed the definitions of the terms contained therein and the interpretation of their meanings. Article (2) clarified the legal personality of the Center, stating that it enjoys the necessary legal personality, such as the capacity to contract, negotiate, and acquire funds,
As this Agreement serves the interest of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and does not conflict with its obligations in the Arab and international spheres, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارة الخارجية</orig> requested the preparation of the necessary legal instrument for its ratification.
And since this Agreement, according to its provisions, requires ratification by law in accordance with the text of the second paragraph of Article (70) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>, its approval shall therefore be by law in accordance with the provision of this paragraph.
Based on Article Four of the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> issued on May 10, 2024, the accompanying draft Decree-Law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig> approving it, along with its explanatory memorandum <orig>مذكرته الإيضاحية</orig>, has been prepared in the appropriate legal format.
Therefore, the accompanying draft Decree-Law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig> approving it, along with its explanatory memorandum <orig>مذكرته الإيضاحية</orig>, has been prepared.

# Headquarters Agreement

Between
The Government of the State of Kuwait and the GCC Emergency Management Center <orig>مركز مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية لإدارة حالات الطوارئ</orig>

Stemming from the resolutions of the Ministerial Council of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> regarding the establishment of the GCC Emergency Management Center <orig>مركز مجلس التعاون لإدارة حالات الطوارئ</orig>, which were adopted during the (121st) session of the Ministerial Council,

And based on Article (2) of the Center's Articles of Association <orig>النظام الأساسي</orig>,

And whereas the Government of the State of Kuwait has agreed to host the GCC Emergency Management Center <orig>مركز مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية لإدارة حالات الطوارئ</orig>, based on Article (3) of the Center's Articles of Association <orig>النظام الأساسي</orig>,

And in the desire of both the Government of the State of Kuwait and the GCC Emergency Management Center <orig>مركز مجلس التعاون لإدارة حالات الطوارئ</orig> to establish the necessary rules for the Center's establishment in Kuwait City <orig>مدينة الكويت</orig> in accordance with the terms of hosting, immunities, and privileges determined by the State of Kuwait, and to achieve the objective of establishing the Center and enable it to carry out its duties and responsibilities in the best possible manner,

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the GCC Emergency Management Center <orig>مركز مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية لإدارة حالات الطوارئ</orig> have agreed as follows:

## Article 1
### Definitions

For the purposes of this Agreement, the terms listed below shall have the following meanings:

The Headquarters: The Center's building, including all attached buildings and lands occupied by the Center and designated for its purposes, whether the Center owns, leases, or occupies them in any other capacity, as well as the President's residence.
Center's Funds: All assets, funds, balances, deposits, and bank accounts managed by the Center to achieve its objectives.
National Committees: The national bodies, councils, committees, or authorities responsible for emergency management in the Member States and their personnel.

## Article 2
### Legal Personality

The Center shall possess the necessary legal personality, including the capacity to contract, negotiate, acquire movable and immovable property, and litigate.

## Article 3
### Purpose of this Agreement

Without prejudice to the laws and regulations applicable in the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, the purpose of this Agreement is to define the tasks undertaken by the Center through the privileges and immunities specified in this Agreement in particular, and the provisions of this Agreement in general.

## Article 4
### Facilities Provided by the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>

The Government undertakes the following:
a- Allocating land for the establishment of the Center's permanent headquarters in accordance with the procedures and mechanisms in force in the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>.

2- The Government shall provide a temporary headquarters for the Center, equipped with all necessary services for it to perform its duties and achieve its objectives, until the permanent headquarters is established, provided that this period does not exceed 3 years.
3- Provision of necessary public services for the Center, such as postal, telephone, and communication services, in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement, in addition to electricity, water, and fire prevention services.

# Article 5
## Immunity of the Center
1- The building of the Center's headquarters shall be inviolable. No employee or person holding any public authority may enter it to perform a duty related to their position except with explicit written permission from the President, and under the conditions approved by them. In cases of necessity, serious reasons for entering the Center must be present.

2- The Government shall take all necessary measures to protect the building and prevent its intrusion, material damage, breach of security, or degradation of its dignity, provided that the Center's buildings are not used for purposes inconsistent with its powers and objectives.
3- The archives and documents of the Center shall be generally inviolable.
4- The Center shall have the right to display its emblem on its buildings.
5- The Center's funds and the means of transport and communication it uses shall not be subject to inspection, seizure, appropriation, or similar coercive measures.
6- The Center, its movable and immovable assets, income, and other properties shall be exempt from all direct taxes. This exemption does not include fees collected for the use of public facilities or in exchange for public services. The Center shall also be exempt from customs duties, prohibitions, and restrictions imposed on the export and import of materials exported or imported by the Center for its official use. Furthermore, the Center may bring funds, securities, and foreign currencies into the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> or transfer them to another country.

### Article 6
### Communication Facilities
The official correspondence and communications of the Center shall not be subject to censorship. The Center has the right to use codes in its correspondence and communications, and it also has the right to use all necessary means of communication, including diplomatic bags. The Center has the right to install wired and wireless communication devices, provided that the necessary approvals are obtained. Furthermore, the Center shall be exempt from all related fees and expenses.

### Article 7
### Immunities and Privileges of Center Members
Without prejudice to the provisions of the Agreement on Privileges and Immunities of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> for the Arab States, signed in Riyadh <orig>الرياض</orig> on 9 Jumada Al-Akhira 1404 AH, corresponding to 11 March 1984, the President, his Deputy, and the Center's staff who are not citizens or residents of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, shall enjoy the following immunities and privileges:
1- Freedom of movement and transit within the territory of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, subject to the regulations and instructions concerning prohibited or restricted areas for reasons related to national security.
2- Judicial immunity for all acts, words, or writings performed by them in their official capacity, and this immunity shall continue even after they cease to hold their official capacity.
3- Immunity from arrest, detention, or confiscation of personal luggage, vehicles, documents, manuscripts, all personal belongings, and intrusion into private residences.
4- Exemption from tax on salaries and emoluments received from the Center.
5- They and their families shall be granted the right to obtain necessary residency permits and return visas, as well as in relation to returning to their home country in times of crisis.

### Article 9
**Application and Interpretation of the Agreement**
In matters not specifically provided for, the provisions of this Agreement shall be applied and interpreted based on relevant international agreements concerning the immunities and privileges accorded to international organizations and their personnel in general.

### Article 10
**Settlement of Disputes**
The Center, in agreement with the Government, shall establish appropriate rules for the settlement of disputes arising from the interpretation and implementation of this Agreement, or any other disputes falling within its scope of work or to which the Center is a party, through amicable means of dispute settlement, negotiations, conciliation, and arbitration.

### Article 11
**Entry into Force, Amendment, Termination**
1- This Agreement shall enter into force from the date of the last notification by which the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> informs the General Secretariat of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> of the completion of all necessary constitutional procedures for its entry into force.
2- This Agreement may be amended by mutual consent of the Parties, and such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures stipulated in paragraph (1) of this Article.
3- This Agreement may be applied provisionally after its signature, in accordance with the provisions of Article (25) of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties of 1969.

# Decree No. 42 of 2025
## Regarding the Appointment of Members to the Board of Directors of Kuwait Petroleum Corporation <orig>مؤسسة البترول الكويتية</orig>

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhul-Qa'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Decree-Law No. 6 of 1980 establishing Kuwait Petroleum Corporation <orig>مؤسسة البترول الكويتية</orig>, amended by Law No. 54 of 1982,
- And the Decree issued on 3 Rabi' Al-Awwal 1400 AH corresponding to 21 January 1980 AD regulating the Board of Directors of Kuwait Petroleum Corporation <orig>مؤسسة البترول الكويتية</orig>, and its amending decrees,
- And Decree No. 72 of 2022 appointing members to the Board of Directors of Kuwait Petroleum Corporation <orig>مؤسسة البترول الكويتية</orig>,
- And Decree No. 84 of 2024 regarding Ministerial Succession and Deputization, and its amending decrees,
- And based on the recommendation of the Minister of Oil,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,
We have decreed the following:

### Article One
The following shall be appointed as members of the Board of Directors of Kuwait Petroleum Corporation <orig>مؤسسة البترول الكويتية</orig> for a period of three years:
1.  Nawaf Saud Al-Nasser Al-Sabah <orig>نواف سعود الناصر الصباح</orig>, Vice Chairman of the Board of Directors - Chief Executive Officer.
2.  Yousef Khalid Yousef Al-Qandi <orig>يوسف خالد يوسف القندي</orig>.
3.  Dr. Sabeeh Abdulaziz Abdulmohsen Al-Mukhaizeem <orig>د. صبيح عبد العزيز عبد المحسن المخيزيم</orig>.
4.  Yousef Abdullah Yousef Al-Yateem <orig>يوسف عبد الله يوسف اليتيم</orig>.
5.  Wafaa Ahmed Abdulaziz Al-Qatami <orig>وفاء أحمد عبد العزيز القطامي</orig>.

### Article Two
The Minister of Oil shall implement this Decree, which shall be effective from the date of its issuance, and it shall be published in the Official Gazette.

Amir of Kuwait
Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>
Acting Prime Minister

Minister of Oil

# Decree No. 45 of 2025
## Regarding the Renewal of Appointment of an Assistant Undersecretary
## in the Government Performance Follow-up Agency <orig>جهاز متابعة الأداء الحكومي</orig>

- Having reviewed the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>,
- And the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Decree-Law No. 15 of 1979 regarding Civil Service <orig>الخدمة المدنية</orig>, and its amending laws,
- And the Decree issued on 7 Jumada al-Ula 1399 AH, corresponding to 4 April 1979 AD, regarding the Civil Service System <orig>نظام الخدمة المدنية</orig>, and its amending decrees,
- And Decree No. 346 of 2007 establishing the Government Performance Follow-up Agency <orig>جهاز متابعة الأداء الحكومي</orig>, amended by Decree No. 175 of 2023,
- And Decree No. 117 of 2021 appointing an Assistant Undersecretary <orig>وكيل وزارة مساعد</orig> in the Government Performance Follow-up Agency <orig>جهاز متابعة الأداء الحكومي</orig>,
- And Decree No. 84 of 2024 regarding Ministerial Substitutions and Delegations <orig>الحلول والإنابات الوزارية</orig>, and its amending decrees,
- And based on the submission of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of State for Cabinet Affairs <orig>نائب رئيس مجلس الوزراء ووزير الدولة لشئون مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,

We have decreed the following:

### Article One
The appointment of / Hamoud Abdul Mohsen Faleh Al-Daihani <orig>حمود عبد المحسن فالح الديحاني</orig> - with the rank of Assistant Undersecretary <orig>وكيل وزارة مساعد</orig> in the Government Performance Follow-up Agency <orig>جهاز متابعة الأداء الحكومي</orig> - is renewed for a period of four years, effective from 9/5/2025.

## Decree No. 46 of 2025 <orig>مرسوم رقم 46 لسنة 2025</orig>
### Regarding the Formation of the Organizations Committee <orig>لجنة المنظمات</orig>
### From the Decisions of the Board of Directors <orig>مجلس إدارة</orig>
### Of the Central Agency for Public Tenders <orig>الجهاز المركزي للمناقصات العامة</orig>
- Having reviewed the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>,
- And the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> issued on 2 Dhu al-Qa'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to May 10, 2024 AD,
- And Law No. 49 of 2016 regarding Public Tenders <orig>المناقصات العامة</orig>, amended by Law No. 74 of 2019, and Law No. 1 of 2024,
- And the Executive Regulations <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية</orig> of Law No. 49 of 2016 regarding Public Tenders, issued by Decree No. 30 of 2017,
- And Decree No. 84 of 2024 regarding Ministerial Substitutions and Delegations <orig>الحلول والإنابات الوزارية</orig>, and its amending decrees,
- And Cabinet Resolution <orig>قرار مجلس الوزراء</orig> No. 431 of 2024 specifying the competent Minister <orig>الوزير المختص</orig> concerning Law No. 49 of 2016 regarding Public Tenders,
- And based on the submission of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of State for Cabinet Affairs <orig>وزير الدولة لشئون مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
We have decreed the following:
### Article One
The Organizations Committee <orig>لجنة المنظمات</orig> of the Board of Directors <orig>مجلس إدارة</orig> of the Central Agency for Public Tenders <orig>الجهاز المركزي للمناقصات العامة</orig> shall be formed for a period of three years – non-renewable – as follows:
1- Qais Mohammed Nisf Al-Nisf <orig>قيس محمد نصف النصف</orig> as Chairman.
2- Engineer Adnan Majed Jassim Bourseli <orig>عدنان ماجد جاسم بورسلي</orig> as Vice Chairman.
3- Zakariya Abdullah Salem Al-Ansari <orig>زكريا عبد الله سالم الأنصاري</orig> as Member.
4- Engineer Dr. Hanouf Mohammed Hamad Al-Humaidi <orig>هنوف محمد حمد الحميدي</orig> as Member.
5- Dr. Munira Saleh Namash Al-Namash <orig>منيرة صالح نمش النمش</orig> as Member.
### Article Two
The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of State for Cabinet Affairs <orig>وزير الدولة لشئون مجلس الوزراء</orig> shall implement this Decree, which shall be effective from the date of its issuance and published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

## Decree No. 49 of 2025
### Regarding the Withdrawal of Kuwaiti Citizenship from Certain Individuals
- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Amiri Decree No. 15 of 1959 regarding the Kuwaiti Nationality Law, and its amending laws,
- And Decree No. 84 of 2024 regarding Ministerial Substitutions and Delegations, and its amending decrees,
- And based on the submission of the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Interior,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,
We have decreed the following:
Article One
Kuwaiti citizenship shall be withdrawn from the following individuals:
1- Ali Ahmed Zubaid <orig>علي أحمد زبيد</orig>.
2- Samer Mohammed Tayeh Saeed Al-Shurafa <orig>سامر محمد تايه سعيد الشرفاء</orig>.
3- Khalid Adnan Mutlaq Nassar Al-Dosari <orig>خالد عدنان مطلق نصار الدوسري</orig>.
4- Khalid Ibrahim Abdullah Ibrahim Al-Rashed <orig>خالد إبراهيم عبدالله إبراهيم الراشد</orig>`.
5- Salem Ali Salem Al-Khammar <orig>سالم علي سالم الخمر</orig>.
6- Khalid Mohammed Qa'id Samir Al-Enezi <orig>خالد محمد قعيد سمير العنزي</orig>.
7- Hisham Abdulbasit Mohammed Al-Saffar <orig>هشام عبدالبسيط محمد الصفار</orig>.
8- Faisal Abdulrahman Ahmed Ali Al-Kandari <orig>فيصل عبدالرحمن أحمد علي الكندري</orig>.
9- Fahad Abdullah Ali Mohammed Mahmoud Al-Kandari <orig>فهد عبدالله علي محمد محمود الكندري</orig>.
10- Fawaz Habib Kayed Baniya Al-Enezi <orig>فواز حبيب كايد بنيه العنزي</orig>.
11- Khalid Mohammed Jaafar Hammoudi <orig>خالد محمد جعفر حمودي</orig>.
12- Khalid Ghazi Sabbar Wisham Alwan Al-Enezi <orig>خالد غازي صبار وشام علوان العنزي</orig>.

14- Mahdi Hassan Mohammed Hassan Al-Hayyani <orig>مهدي حسن محمد حسن الحياني</orig>.
15- Saad Fahim Saeed Dhaher <orig>سعد فاهم سعيد ظاهر</orig>.
16- Fahad Mohammed Hassan Mohammed Abdullah <orig>فهد محمد حسن محمد عبدالله</orig>.

# Decree No. 50 of 2025
Approving a Memorandum of Understanding
Between the Government of the State of Kuwait
And the Government of the Republic of Austria
Regarding Cooperation in Consular Affairs

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Decree No. 84 of 2024 regarding Ministerial Substitutions and Delegations and its amending decrees,
- And based on the submission of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,

We have decreed the following:

## Article One
Approval of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Austria regarding cooperation in consular affairs, signed in New York City on 26 September 2024, the texts of which are attached to this Decree.

## Article Two
Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.

Amir of Kuwait
Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>

Acting Prime Minister
Fahad Yusuf Saud Al-Sabah <orig>فهد يوسف سعود الصباح</orig>

Minister of Foreign Affairs
Abdullah Ali Abdullah Al-Yahya <orig>عبد الله علي عبد الله اليحيا</orig>

Issued at Seif Palace on: 18 Ramadan 1446 AH
Corresponding to: 18 March 2025 AD<image_caption>Kuwait Government Official Seal</image_caption>

# Memorandum of Understanding
Between
The Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>
And
The Government of the Republic of Austria
Concerning Cooperation in Consular Affairs

The Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Republic of Austria (hereinafter referred to as "the Parties"),
Desiring to promote and strengthen cooperation between them,
And recognizing the importance of regular mutual consultations on bilateral relations and international issues of common interest between the two countries,
And taking into account efforts to enhance political dialogue and consultations on bilateral issues,
With the aim of expanding this cooperation to include consular issues between the two countries,
Have agreed as follows:

### Article 1
The Parties shall hold consular consultations to review all aspects of consular assistance, exchange views on changes and developments in the consular field, and identify problems within this scope.
The agenda, dates, venue, and composition of delegations shall be determined through diplomatic channels upon the initiative of either Party.

### Article 2
The Parties shall exchange expertise on consular assistance during crises, epidemics, armed conflict, natural disasters, and other difficult circumstances.

## Paragraph 3
The Parties acknowledge that, with regard to citizens of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Republic of Austria <orig>جمهورية النمسا</orig> who reside in the other respective State and do not possess a valid residence permit or do not have the right to remain, and who do not choose to return voluntarily, they shall be returned on a non-voluntary basis without delay, and the transit of such citizens shall be facilitated. In this regard, citizens of both Parties holding valid travel documents shall be readmitted and returned without additional restrictions; for citizens of both Parties who do not possess valid travel documents, a travel document shall be issued upon identification by the competent authorities without delay.
The Parties shall assist each other in cases of readmission and air transit of citizens of either Party who are transferred from the territory of the other Party.

## Paragraph 4
The Parties shall hold consultations on practical measures to facilitate bilateral political and consular dialogue, including the possibility of concluding an agreement on visa exemption for holders of diplomatic and special passports.

## Paragraph 5
The provisions of this Memorandum of Understanding <orig>مذكرة التفاهم</orig> shall not affect the national laws in force for both sides, nor their rights and obligations arising from international treaties and agreements to which they are parties.
This Memorandum of Understanding <orig>مذكرة التفاهم</orig> shall not create any legal obligation for either Party.
Either side may refuse cooperation under this Memorandum of Understanding <orig>مذكرة التفاهم</orig> if it conflicts with the constitution or the fundamental principles of that Party's national law.

## Paragraph 6
Each side shall bear the costs incurred by its competent authorities in implementing the Memorandum of Understanding <orig>مذكرة التفاهم</orig>, unless the Parties agree otherwise.

### Paragraph 8
1. This Memorandum of Understanding shall enter into force from the date of receipt of the last notification by which one Party informs the other Party, in writing and through diplomatic channels, of the fulfillment of its internal procedures necessary for its entry into force.
2. This Memorandum of Understanding may be amended in writing by agreement of the Parties, at any time. Such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures set forth in paragraph 1 of this Article.
3. This Memorandum of Understanding shall remain in force for a period of (5) years from the date of its entry into force, and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period or periods, unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing, and through diplomatic channels, of its desire to terminate this Agreement (6) months prior to its expiry date.
4. The termination of this Memorandum of Understanding shall not affect the validity or duration of any specific agreements, projects, and activities undertaken pursuant to this Memorandum of Understanding.

Preamble
1. The Middle East Green Initiative <orig>مبادرة الشرق الأوسط الأخضر</orig> was announced during the Initiative's first summit, held in Riyadh, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia <orig>المملكة العربية السعودية</orig>, on October 25, 2021. It aims to create a platform to enhance regional cooperation and mobilize international support for land restoration, preserve vegetation cover, and encourage international integration of regional efforts. This document represents the Charter of the Middle East Green Initiative <orig>مبادرة الشرق الأوسط الأخضر</orig> for land restoration and preservation. It includes defining the framework for regional decision-making governance and overseeing activities and projects sponsored or supported by the region's countries, as agreed upon by the participating countries of the region.
2. This Charter was prepared in English as the official language of the reference document. Following the adoption of the Middle East Green Initiative <orig>مبادرة الشرق الأوسط الأخضر</orig> Charter at the Ministerial Meeting held on October 26, 2022, the abstract reference document in English may be translated into Arabic and French, which will be used for informational purposes only. The translated document shall not be legally binding and is subject to the approval of the Ministerial Council <orig>المجلس الوزاري</orig> upon its formation.

Initiative Drivers and Objectives:
3. Land degradation and the associated loss of natural terrestrial habitats represent one of the pivotal challenges of the 21st century. This degradation affects the livelihoods of over 3.3 billion people, of whom 1.3 billion depend on agricultural lands suffering from continuous desertification, which consequently impacts their food security. The loss of natural habitats resulting from changes in land use or degradation is one of the primary causes of biodiversity loss. If this continues, it will lead to the loss of between 38% and 46% of living species by 2050. Land degradation contributes to climate change by increasing greenhouse gas emissions and reducing natural carbon absorption rates, while simultaneously exacerbating desertification. The annual losses resulting from land degradation and its consequent challenges, through its impact on environmental loss, which has been ongoing for decades, amount to 300 billion US dollars annually, representing more than 10% of the gross domestic product.
4. Countries in West, Central, and South Asia, North Africa, and Sub-Saharan Africa are among the regions most affected by land degradation globally, which in turn impacts the environmental, social, and economic aspects of these countries. Estimates indicate that 29% of degraded lands are located in countries facing a range of human challenges, and it is also estimated that approximately 50 million hectares of these degraded lands are located in West, Central, and South Asia, North Africa, and Sub-Saharan Africa. Consequently, the Middle East Green Initiative <orig>مبادرة الشرق الأوسط الأخضر</orig> aims to bring together countries of the region and international organizations from across the region and the world to enhance cooperation in implementing nature-based solutions to halt and reduce land degradation and promote land conservation through the use of innovations and best practices, leveraging regional cooperation, and mobilizing international support under the supervision of inclusive and transparent participatory regional governance.
5. The Initiative draws upon the Rio Conventions <orig>اتفاقيات رو ريو</orig> on Biodiversity, Climate Change, and Desertification, the 2030 Agenda, including the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, and the G20 Global Initiative on Reducing Land Degradation and Enhancing Terrestrial Ecosystems. The Initiative aims to mitigate losses in terrestrial habitat conservation. It is expected to promote and support regional activities/projects aimed at enhancing the management of terrestrial ecosystems; restoring degraded lands; and promoting the conservation and sustainable management of vegetation cover and terrestrial habitats in the region to achieve the Initiative's goal of planting or rehabilitating 50 billion trees, equivalent to restoring 200 million hectares of land, throughout the Initiative's duration.

* Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (2019). "Assessment Report on Land Degradation and Restoration." And the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (2019). "Summary for Policymakers" in "Climate Change and Land: An IPCC Special Report on Climate Change, Desertification, Land Degradation, Sustainable Land Management, Food Security, and Greenhouse Gas Fluxes in Terrestrial Ecosystems."
* Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (2019). "Assessment Report on Land Degradation and Restoration."
* Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (2019). "Summary for Policymakers."
* Economics of Land Degradation Initiative (2015). "The Value of Land."
* Food and Agriculture Organization (2021). "The State of the World's Land and Water Resources for Food and Agriculture."

The scope of the Middle East Green Initiative <orig>مبادرة الشرق الأوسط الأخضر</orig> and its regional governance are guided by the following fundamental principles:
- A Shared Vision for a Sustainable Future: The Initiative is based on crystallizing a green and sustainable regional vision within a changing climate.

Guiding Principles for the Launch of the Middle East Green Initiative:
The scope and regional governance of the Middle East Green Initiative are guided by the following fundamental principles:
- Shared Vision for a Sustainable Future: The Initiative is based on crystallizing a green and sustainable regional vision within a changing climate.
- Cooperative and Comprehensive Oversight: The Initiative is based on regional cooperation for overseeing activities and projects, effective national participation, involving everyone in the decision-making process, cooperation with the private sector, and close participation by regional and international civil organizations to provide consultation.
- Accountability and Transparency: The Initiative's transparent governance mechanisms will provide full clarity of its proceedings to all member states and partners. Its robust financial management mechanisms will adopt best practices, strict regional oversight, and national participation to ensure integrity and responsibility in the implementation of activities and projects sponsored by the Initiative to achieve its desired objectives.
- National, Regional, and International Linkages: The Initiative will work to foster close alignment between national, regional, and global goals and efforts related to combating land degradation, promoting vegetation restoration and preservation, and pursuing fruitful cooperation with other relevant regional and global environmental initiatives.
- Science-Based Decision Making: The Initiative will strive to achieve the greatest possible impact from its activities by following strict scientific principles in project selection and design, engaging leading regional and international expertise, and promoting knowledge exchange of best practices and technology transfer among member states and relevant regional and international organizations.
- Innovation-Driven Action: The Initiative will work to disseminate innovative solutions at both regional and international levels in pursuit of achieving sustainable development goals, including in affected areas, by reducing negative environmental impact, increasing adaptability and resilience, and utilizing natural resources in an efficient and responsible manner.
- Joint Collaborative Approach: Among governmental bodies at the national level: The implementation of projects and activities supported by the Initiative will rely on national coordination bodies that promote inter-sectoral and vertical cooperation within and across relevant government entities to facilitate synergy of efforts and manage negotiation processes, thereby supporting integration processes between the various areas of the Initiative, especially economic, social, and environmental.
- Maximizing Social and Economic Benefits: The activities and projects supported by the Initiative will contribute to fostering a sustainable future for the region's population and maximizing their social and economic well-being, in addition to enhancing cooperation in areas related to transboundary natural resources.

## Scope of the Initiative

- The Initiative works to facilitate cooperation and provide support to member states from the region in Central, West, and South Asia, North Africa, and Sub-Saharan Africa, to address land degradation and promote the restoration of degraded lands and the preservation of vegetation cover, pastures, agricultural lands, and other vegetation areas, through the use of nature-based solutions and an ecosystem-based approach, ensuring regional alignment and providing a regional governance framework, along with providing oversight, technical, and financial support services for the Initiative's activities and projects throughout all their stages.
- Financial support for the Initiative's projects and activities will be provided through the provision of funds and/or facilitating access to private capital and other financing mechanisms, which may include:
  - Utilizing blended finance to mobilize private investments, which may include, but is not limited to, co-financing for projects involving additional parties, such as donor-funded funds or grants from building funds or grants from private sector donors, or concessional lending from development banks or private sector investments, or other financing programs supported by the Initiative, or all of the above.
  - Obtaining the necessary accreditation to access green finance, including sustainability bonds.

# Governance
8. The Initiative's activities and projects will be overseen by the Ministerial Council of the Initiative <orig>المجلس الوزاري للمبادرة</orig> at two interconnected levels: a regional governance structure to facilitate decision-making at the regional level, and a national governance structure to facilitate the identification, coordination, and oversight of activities and projects within the Initiative's member states.

## The Ministerial Council
### 9. Role and Responsibilities
The Ministerial Council <orig>المجلس الوزاري</orig> represents the highest oversight authority for the Initiative and the supreme environment for strategic decision-making, in order to define the Initiative's strategic direction and ensure the alignment of all activities with the Initiative's long-term objectives. The Council reviews and approves proposed strategic plans and budgets, appoints the Secretary-General of the Initiative <orig>الأمين العام للمبادرة</orig>, and approves the organizational structure of the Initiative's Secretariat <orig>أمانة المبادرة</orig>, its internal regulations, and other general strategic decisions for the organization that are submitted by the Executive Committee <orig>اللجنة التنفيذية</orig> to the Ministerial Council <orig>المجلس الوزاري</orig>.

### 10. Council Membership
All member states in the region are represented in the Ministerial Council <orig>المجلس الوزاري</orig> by one representative from each state. The Council consists of civilian ministers entrusted with national responsibilities related to the scope of the Initiative's work.
States from outside the region may participate in the meetings of the Ministerial Council <orig>المجلس الوزاري</orig> as observers, provided that the Ministerial Council <orig>المجلس الوزاري</orig> approves this.
The Council is chaired by a president elected by the members, with the position rotating. The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia <orig>المملكة العربية السعودية</orig> will assume the first presidency of the Ministerial Council <orig>المجلس الوزاري</orig> upon its establishment for two consecutive years, exceptionally, to ensure continuity throughout the Initiative's establishment process.
